A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A laser is a device that produces a beam of light. A design, shown above, is etched onto a flat piece of metal using a moving laser. The position of the laser at time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds is represented by <math alttext="the point with coordinates x of t comma y of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the <math alttext="x y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane. Both <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in centimeters, and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds. The laser starts at position <math alttext="0 comma 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the design takes <math alttext="3.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds to complete. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 3.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="the derivative of x with respect to t, equal 3 times, the cosine of, open parenthesis, t squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals 4 times, the cosine of, open parenthesis, 2.5 t, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mi>cos</mi> <mo>⁡</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>2.5</mn> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

frqParts.text: (a) Find the speed of the laser at time <math alttext="t equals 3" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> seconds.

(b) Find the total distance traveled by the laser from time <math alttext="t equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds.

(c) The laser is farthest to the right at time <math alttext="t equals 1.253" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.253</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds. Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the laser’s rightmost position.

(d) What is the difference between the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinates of the laser’s highest position and lowest position for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 3.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?  Justify your answer.
